clusters.title: The ceasefire in Gaza remains fragile after return of hostages and prisoners
clusters.neutral_headline: Ceasefire in Gaza Remains Fragile Despite Hostage Release

items.title: The ceasefire in Gaza remains fragile after return of hostages and prisoners
items.standfirst: As Israelis and Palestinians celebrate the release of their loved ones as part of the US-brokered truce, the peace deal remains fragile. The two sides have yet to agree on Gaza’s postwar governance, the territory’s reconstruction and Israel’s demand that Hamas disarm. Negotiations over those issues could still break down.
items.content: As Israelis and Palestinians celebrate the release of their loved ones as part of the US-brokered truce, the peace deal remains fragile. The two sides have yet to agree on Gaza’s postwar governance, the territory’s reconstruction and Israel’s demand that Hamas disarm. Negotiations over those issues could still break down.

items.title: Who are the released hostages?
items.standfirst: The Israeli military says 20 living hostages have been released by Hamas and have returned to Israel.
items.content: The Israeli military says 20 living hostages have been released by Hamas and have returned to Israel.

items.title: 'What's happening in Gaza is a sort of anarchy', as complex issues remain for Israel-Hamas ceasefire
items.standfirst: Israel and Hamas took an initial step in a fragile Gaza ceasefire on Monday by exchanging hostages and prisoners, offering hope for a lasting peace. However, major issues like Hamas disarming, future governance of Gaza, and Palestinian statehood remain unresolved, as FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky explains. To her, 'what's happening in Gaza is a sort of anarchy' as humanitarian aid trickles in but the enclave remains closed.
items.content: Israel and Hamas took an initial step in a fragile Gaza ceasefire on Monday by exchanging hostages and prisoners, offering hope for a lasting peace. However, major issues like Hamas disarming, future governance of Gaza, and Palestinian statehood remain unresolved, as FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky explains. To her, 'what's happening in Gaza is a sort of anarchy' as humanitarian aid trickles in but the enclave remains closed.

items.title: ‘We are here’: Parents of deceased Israeli hostage react to hostage release
items.standfirst: While many Israelis celebrate the release of hostages and family reunions, others continue to endure pain as they await the return of loved ones' remains who were killed inside Gaza. The parents of Hersh Goldberg-Polin, whose body was recovered in August, 2024, discuss the feelings of the families who are still waiting and share their thoughts on the peace deal with NBC News' Tom Llamas.
items.content: While many Israelis celebrate the release of hostages and family reunions, others continue to endure pain as they await the return of loved ones' remains who were killed inside Gaza. The parents of Hersh Goldberg-Polin, whose body was recovered in August, 2024, discuss the feelings of the families who are still waiting and share their thoughts on the peace deal with NBC News' Tom Llamas.

clusters.title: Madagascar President in Hiding as Gen Z Topples Another Government
clusters.neutral_headline: Madagascar President Flees Amidst Protests and Military Unrest

items.title: Madagascar President in Hiding as Gen Z Topples Another Government
items.standfirst: The president of Madagascar, Andry Rajoelina, has fled the African nation to become the latest world leader ousted by Gen Z-driven unrest sweeping across the world. Following demonstrations over living conditions in which army members joined protests, Rajoelina was evacuated from the country…
items.content: The president of Madagascar, Andry Rajoelina, has fled the African nation to become the latest world leader ousted by Gen Z-driven unrest sweeping across the world. Following demonstrations over living conditions in which army members joined protests, Rajoelina was evacuated from the country…

items.title: Deadly protests force Madagascar’s president to flee
items.standfirst: Madagascar’s President Andry Rajoelina refused to resign but reportedly fled the country after army defections and protests demanding his ouster. His departure sparked celebrations in Antananarivo, with protesters comparing it to a second independence. The protests, triggered by shortages and corruption, have caused at least 22 deaths. French President Macron stressed the need for constitutional order but did not confirm Rajoelina’s reported escape on a French military plane.
items.content: Madagascar’s President Andry Rajoelina refused to resign but reportedly fled the country after army defections and protests demanding his ouster. His departure sparked celebrations in Antananarivo, with protesters comparing it to a second independence. The protests, triggered by shortages and corruption, have caused at least 22 deaths. French President Macron stressed the need for constitutional order but did not confirm Rajoelina’s reported escape on a French military plane.

items.title: Madagascar president says he fled country in fear for his life
items.standfirst: Andry Rajoelina does not announce resignation in speech broadcast on social media after military rebellionMadagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, said he had fled the country in fear for his life after a military rebellion but did not announce his resignation in a speech broadcast on social media late on Monday from an undisclosed location.The 51-year-old has faced weeks of gen Z-led anti-government protests, which reached a pivotal point on Saturday when an elite military unit joined the protests and called for the president and other ministers to step down. That prompted Rajoelina to say that an illegal attempt to seize power was under way in the Indian Ocean island and to leave the country. Continue reading...
items.content: Andry Rajoelina does not announce resignation in speech broadcast on social media after military rebellionMadagascar’s president, Andry Rajoelina, said he had fled the country in fear for his life after a military rebellion but did not announce his resignation in a speech broadcast on social media late on Monday from an undisclosed location.The 51-year-old has faced weeks of gen Z-led anti-government protests, which reached a pivotal point on Saturday when an elite military unit joined the protests and called for the president and other ministers to step down. That prompted Rajoelina to say that an illegal attempt to seize power was under way in the Indian Ocean island and to leave the country. Continue reading...

items.title: Madagascar's president flees country in fear for his life after military rebellion
items.standfirst: Madagascar President Andry Rajoelina called for dialogue "to find a way out of this situation" and said the constitution should be respected.
items.content: Madagascar President Andry Rajoelina called for dialogue "to find a way out of this situation" and said the constitution should be respected.(Image credit: Alexander Joe)

items.title: President of Madagascar flees to ‘safe location’ amid deadly protests
items.standfirst: Andry Rajoelina confirmed his departure on Monday, following reports he had been evacuated by a French aircraft.
items.content: Andry Rajoelina confirmed his departure on Monday, following reports he had been evacuated by a French aircraft.

items.title: Madagascar’s president says illegal power grab by military is under way
items.standfirst: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protestsMadagascar’s president said an “attempt to seize power illegally and by force” was under way, as an elite military unit that joined protesters on the streets on Saturday announced it was taking over the army.The Capsat unit’s intervention comes after weeks of youth-led protests, which started on 25 September against water and electricity shortages and expanded to calling for the resignation of the president, Andry Rajoelina, an end to corruption and radical overhaul of the political system. Continue reading...
items.content: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protestsMadagascar’s president said an “attempt to seize power illegally and by force” was under way, as an elite military unit that joined protesters on the streets on Saturday announced it was taking over the army.The Capsat unit’s intervention comes after weeks of youth-led protests, which started on 25 September against water and electricity shortages and expanded to calling for the resignation of the president, Andry Rajoelina, an end to corruption and radical overhaul of the political system. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Madagascar's President Rajoelina reportedly fled the country after protests.
Protests were triggered by shortages and corruption, causing at least 22 deaths.
An elite military unit joined protests, calling for the president to step down.
Rajoelina said he fled in fear for his life but did not announce resignation.
The president called for dialogue and respect for the constitution.

Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Israelis and Palestinians celebrate as truce brings hope of ‘era of peace’
items.standfirst: UN warns Gaza still needs ‘lifesaving aid’ as world leaders gather in Sharm el-Sheikh to discuss 20-point proposalThere was a rare moment of joy among Israelis and Palestinians on Monday as Hamas released the remaining 20 living hostages in Gaza as part of a swap deal for nearly 2,000 Palestinian detainees, on a day world leaders met in Egypt to try to ensure the current limited truce is extended into a durable peace.“The prayers of millions have finally been answered,” Donald Trump declared at the peace summit, with his counterparts lined up behind him. “At long last, we have peace in the Middle East.” Continue reading...
items.content: UN warns Gaza still needs ‘lifesaving aid’ as world leaders gather in Sharm el-Sheikh to discuss 20-point proposalThere was a rare moment of joy among Israelis and Palestinians on Monday as Hamas released the remaining 20 living hostages in Gaza as part of a swap deal for nearly 2,000 Palestinian detainees, on a day world leaders met in Egypt to try to ensure the current limited truce is extended into a durable peace.“The prayers of millions have finally been answered,” Donald Trump declared at the peace summit, with his counterparts lined up behind him. “At long last, we have peace in the Middle East.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: Death toll from Mexico floods rises to 64 as search operation expands
clusters.neutral_headline: Mexico Flooding Death Toll Rises to 64, Search Continues

items.title: Death toll from Mexico floods rises to 64 as search operation expands
items.standfirst: The death toll from torrential rains that lashed Mexico has risen to 64 people with 65 more reported missing across five states, according to official figures. Mexico has deployed some 10,000 troops in addition to civilian rescue teams to try to reach communities that remain cut off due to the disaster.
items.content: The death toll from torrential rains that lashed Mexico has risen to 64 people with 65 more reported missing across five states, according to official figures. Mexico has deployed some 10,000 troops in addition to civilian rescue teams to try to reach communities that remain cut off due to the disaster.

clusters.title: French Prime Minister to announce cuts in new austerity budget
clusters.neutral_headline: French Prime Minister to Announce Cuts in New Austerity Budget

items.title: French Prime Minister to announce cuts in new austerity budget
items.standfirst: As he faces two potential no-confidence votes, French PM Sébastien Lecornu is to outline his budget plans in his address to Parliament. He is expected to present an austerity budget which would cut 30 billion euros in spending, while prolonging a temporary surtax on high-earners and companies earning more than one billion annually, although cut by half. FRANCE 24's Antonia Kerrigan tells us more from the Elysée Palace in Paris.
items.content: As he faces two potential no-confidence votes, French PM Sébastien Lecornu is to outline his budget plans in his address to Parliament. He is expected to present an austerity budget which would cut 30 billion euros in spending, while prolonging a temporary surtax on high-earners and companies earning more than one billion annually, although cut by half. FRANCE 24's Antonia Kerrigan tells us more from the Elysée Palace in Paris.

items.title: Crypto Market Sheds $150 Billion as China Hits Back at the US
items.standfirst: Cryptocurrencies continued to lose ground after a historic round of liquidations that triggered a sharp selloff over the weekend, as trade tensions weighed on risk assets. Bitcoin, the largest digital asset, slumped as much as 4% to about $111,200 on Tuesday morning in London, while Ether fell…

items.title: US-China trade tensions escalate as tit-for-tat port fees come into effect
items.standfirst: Port fees imposed by China and the US took effect on Tuesday, adding a new front to the trade war between the world’s two largest economies. In this edition, we explore the reasons behind these new fees and their impact on the broader talks between Washington and Beijing. Also, we examine how US soybean farmers are being affected by China’s halt on imports of US-produced soybeans.
items.content: Port fees imposed by China and the US took effect on Tuesday, adding a new front to the trade war between the world’s two largest economies. In this edition, we explore the reasons behind these new fees and their impact on the broader talks between Washington and Beijing. Also, we examine how US soybean farmers are being affected by China’s halt on imports of US-produced soybeans.

ai_summary: China and US port fees took effect, adding a new front to trade war.
France24 explores reasons for fees and impact on Washington-Beijing talks.
US soybean farmers are affected by China's halt on US soybean imports.
Reuters notes market drop triggered by renewed trade tensions.
Bank of America suggests buying two stocks amid trade war concerns.

ai_summary: Trump stated the war between Israel and Hamas is over.

items.title: Cape Verde makes historic qualifier for 2026 FIFA World Cup
items.standfirst: Cape Verde makes history as it qualifies for the 2026 FIFA World Cup. The tiny island-nation becomes the second smallest ever to make it to the prestigious competition.
items.content: Cape Verde makes history as it qualifies for the 2026 FIFA World Cup. The tiny island-nation becomes the second smallest ever to make it to the prestigious competition.

items.title: Cape Verde clinches historic first qualification for FIFA World Cup
items.standfirst: The island nation, located off the African coast, becomes the second-smallest country to qualify for the World Cup.
items.content: The island nation, located off the African coast, becomes the second-smallest country to qualify for the World Cup.

items.standfirst: Doug Lebda died on Sunday in an all-terrain vehicle accident, according to LendingTree.
items.content: Doug Lebda died on Sunday in an all-terrain vehicle accident, according to LendingTree.

ai_summary: Doug Lebda, LendingTree founder, died in an ATV accident.
The accident occurred on his family's farm on Sunday.
Lebda was 55 years old at the time of his death.
He founded LendingTree in 1996.

clusters.title: Eurovision emergency vote on Israel's inclusion is called off

items.title: Eurovision emergency vote on Israel's inclusion is called off
items.standfirst: An emergency vote on Israel's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest has been called off following developments in the Middle East, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) has said.
items.content: An emergency vote on Israel's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest has been called off following developments in the Middle East, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) has said.

items.title: Eurovision organisers postpone vote on Israel's inclusion in contest next year
items.standfirst: The European Broadcasting Union had previously announced it would hold a vote on Israel's participation in November.
items.content: The European Broadcasting Union had previously announced it would hold a vote on Israel's participation in November.

ai_summary: An emergency vote on Israel's participation was called off.
The European Broadcasting Union made the announcement.
The vote was postponed due to developments in the Middle East.

clusters.title: US news outlets say they will not agree to Pentagon reporting restrictions
clusters.neutral_headline: US news outlets refuse Pentagon reporting restrictions

items.title: US news outlets say they will not agree to Pentagon reporting restrictions
items.standfirst: Reporters must promise not to publish unauthorised material to obtain press credentials.
items.content: Reporters must promise not to publish unauthorised material to obtain press credentials.

items.title: US news outlets refuse to sign new Pentagon rules to report only official information
items.standfirst: Defense department policy requires outlets to vow not to obtain unauthorized files and restricts access to some areasSeveral leading news organizations with access to Pentagon briefings have formally said they will not agree to a new defense department policy that requires them to pledge they will not obtain unauthorized material and restricts access to certain areas unless accompanied by an official.The policy, presented last month by the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, has been widely criticized by media organizations asked to sign the pledge by Tuesday at 5pm or have 24 hours to turn in their press credentials. Continue reading...
items.content: Defense department policy requires outlets to vow not to obtain unauthorized files and restricts access to some areasSeveral leading news organizations with access to Pentagon briefings have formally said they will not agree to a new defense department policy that requires them to pledge they will not obtain unauthorized material and restricts access to certain areas unless accompanied by an official.The policy, presented last month by the defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, has been widely criticized by media organizations asked to sign the pledge by Tuesday at 5pm or have 24 hours to turn in their press credentials. Continue reading...

ai_summary: US news outlets will not sign new Pentagon rules.
The rules require outlets to not publish unauthorized material.
The policy restricts access to some areas.
Media organizations must sign the pledge or lose credentials.

items.standfirst: Starship, the biggest and most powerful rocket ever built, thundered into the evening sky from the southern tip of Texas.
items.content: Starship, the biggest and most powerful rocket ever built, thundered into the evening sky from the southern tip of Texas.(Image credit: Eric Gay)

items.title: SpaceX launches 11th test flight of giant Super Heavy-Starship rocket

items.content: Starship — the biggest and most powerful rocket ever built — thundered into the evening sky from the southern tip of Texas on Monday.

ai_summary: SpaceX launched the 11th test flight of Starship.
Starship is the biggest and most powerful rocket.
The launch occurred from the southern tip of Texas.

clusters.title: Markets rebound amid latest US-China tariff spat as traders look to possible ‘Taco trade’
clusters.neutral_headline: Markets rebound amid US-China tariff spat

items.title: Markets rebound amid latest US-China tariff spat as traders look to possible ‘Taco trade’
items.standfirst: US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes rise and cryptocurrencies rebound after Trump post on Truth SocialBusiness live – latest updatesGlobal stock markets have edged higher and cryptocurrencies rebounded amid signs that a new front in the US-China trade war may not be as severe as first feared.Tensions between Washington and Beijing escalated again on Friday and over the weekend, as Donald Trump threatened to impose additional US tariffs of 100% on China starting next month. Continue reading...
items.content: US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes rise and cryptocurrencies rebound after Trump post on Truth SocialBusiness live – latest updatesGlobal stock markets have edged higher and cryptocurrencies rebounded amid signs that a new front in the US-China trade war may not be as severe as first feared.Tensions between Washington and Beijing escalated again on Friday and over the weekend, as Donald Trump threatened to impose additional US tariffs of 100% on China starting next month. Continue reading...

items.title: China warns US of retaliation over Trump’s 100% tariffs threat
items.standfirst: Beijing says it will act if US president doesn’t stand down, while investors brace for trade war turmoilBeijing has told the US it will retaliate if Donald Trump fails to back down on his threat to impose 100% tariffs on Chinese imports as investors brace for another bout of trade war turmoil.China’s commerce ministry blamed Washington for raising trade tensions between the two countries after Trump announced on Friday that he would impose the additional tariffs on China’s exports to the US, along with new controls on critical software, by 1 November. Continue reading...
items.content: Beijing says it will act if US president doesn’t stand down, while investors brace for trade war turmoilBeijing has told the US it will retaliate if Donald Trump fails to back down on his threat to impose 100% tariffs on Chinese imports as investors brace for another bout of trade war turmoil.China’s commerce ministry blamed Washington for raising trade tensions between the two countries after Trump announced on Friday that he would impose the additional tariffs on China’s exports to the US, along with new controls on critical software, by 1 November. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Markets rebounded amid the latest US-China tariff spat.
US S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes rose.
Cryptocurrencies also rebounded after Trump's post.
Trump threatened to impose 100% tariffs on China.
China warned the US of retaliation if tariffs are imposed.
